article_title: 766,000 Texans fall into Medicaid coverage gap
article_text:
766,000 Texans fall into Medicaid coverage gap State’s refusal to expand keeps them uninsured

Photo: Express-News File Photo The Kaiser Family Foundation finds that more than 4.4 million...

As Texas continues to lead the nation in the number of uninsured, a new study has found that more than three-quarters of a million Texans may have little chance of getting health care coverage because the state chose not to expand Medicaid.

article_metadata.description: In all, more than 4.4 million Texans are without health care insurance, both the highest number and the highest rate in the country, this study shows.  With only a couple of weeks to go until the new enrollment period opens for the federally mandated marketplace plans, the Kaiser study was designed to shed light on who remains uninsured — and if there are options available to them.  In Texas, that share shrinks to about a third,” said Rachel Garfield, a senior researcher at the foundation and co-author of the study, adding “the pattern for Texas is quite different.  When the ACA was written, it was assumed that the lowest income group would be covered by an expanded Medicaid network, and federal subsidies for coverage on state exchanges or in the federal marketplace would kick in if a person or family earned 100 percent of the poverty line.  Garfield said one reason people may not be getting insurance is that even if they fall just over the line to have enough income to buy it out of pocket or are offered an employer plan, policies might still feel out of reach for those with tight budgets.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam, Houston Chronicle

When the ACA was written, it was assumed that the lowest income group would be covered by an expanded Medicaid network, and federal subsidies for coverage on state exchanges or in the federal marketplace would kick in if a person or family earned 100 percent of the poverty line.
